alert.note: Alert for Calhoun; Clarendon; Richland; Sumter (South Carolina) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Advisory issued August 30 at 6:44PM EDT until August 30 at 9:30PM EDT by NWS Columbia
info.description: ...FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 845 PM EDT THIS EVENING... * WHAT...Urban and small stream flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected. * WHERE...A portion of central South Carolina, including the following counties, Calhoun, Clarendon, Kershaw, Lee, Richland and Sumter. * WHEN...Until 845 PM EDT. * IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas. Overflowing poor drainage areas. Ponding of water in urban or other areas is occurring or is imminent. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 644 PM EDT, Doppler radar and automated rain gauges indicated heavy rain due to thunderstorms. This will cause urban and small stream flooding. Between 1 and 2 inches of rain have fallen. - Additional rainfall amounts up to 1 inch are expected over the area. This additional rain will result in minor flooding. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Columbia, Sumter, Camden, Manning, Bishopville, South Sumter, Shaw Air Base, McEntire Air Base, Elgin, Eastover, Millwood, Sumter County Airport, Mulberry, Oakland, Poinsett State Park, Alcolu, Elliott, Lee State Park, Goodale State Park and Gadsden. - This includes the following highways... Interstate 95 between mile markers 112 and 146. Interstate 20 in South Carolina between mile markers 78 and 126. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
info.instruction: Most flooding deaths occur in vehicles. Never drive through a flooded roadway or around barricades. Turn around, don`t drown. Flooded roadways are nearly impossible to see at night. Avoid traveling in this area. Turn around, don`t drown. Be aware of your surroundings and do not drive on flooded roads. Report any flooding directly to the Columbia National Weather Service at 803 234 4115 when it is safe to do so. You can also send reports by Facebook or Twitter to NWSColumbia or by e-mail at NWS.Columbia@noaa.gov.
